Product Description

Description

Suitable for the thickness between 1mm to 5mm of the mounting board.

Ideal choice for electrical wiring in the power switches, speed switches and asynchronous motor for their start-up and reversing, also can make the conversion of the control circuit.

Widely used as circuit control switches, test equipment switches, motor control switches and master control switches, signal transfer switches, or change-over switch for electric welding machinery and other equipment.

Image3 has shown which terminal will be connected in different position , please read the wiring diagram as a reference.

Position 1 : 1-2 , 5-6

Position 0 : All terminal disconnected

Position 2 : 3-4 , 7-8

Specifications

Model: LW28-32/2

Positions: 3

Terminals: 8

Ui: 690V Ith: 32A

Action Type: Latching

Positioning angle: 60-0-60 Degree

Rating: DC-13: Ui: 220V, Ith: 0.14A; AC-15: Ue / Ie: 380V / 1.5A

Mounting Hole Distance: 48mm x 48mm / 1.89inch x 1.89inch (L*W)

Total Size: 65mm x 65mm x 94mm / 2.59inch x 2.59inch x 3.7inch (L*W*H)

Package Content

1 x Changeover Switch

4 x Mounting Screws

Mark Vermont

5.0 out of 5 stars Great 4-contact switch for off grid solar

Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2024

Size: 16 Terminals 63AVerified Purchase

I needed a switch that would let me disconnect the solar from feeding the subpanel in my shop and give me the option of connecting the shop sub panel to my generator, which is portable. Because of the way safety is maintained by complying with code, regarding ground neutral bonding, I wanted to switch that would disconnect not just the hots, but also the neutral in the ground so I could maintain my solar inverter system as the source of ground because it is the source of power and still leave my portable generator bonded without creating two neutral ground bonds in one system . This switch allowed me to do that for my 3000W system with a positive disconnect of the neutral and ground.

Works great, time will tell on longevity outdoors
Amazon Customer
4 out of 5 stars
Works great, time will tell on longevity outdoors
The need: Added this switch on to my car hauler. I put led lights up on the tire rack to shine down on the bed and put some led lights by the ramp loading area and under the front to help with hitch hookup in dark. I needed a waterproof enclosed switch to handle the 12vdc switching. The Product: The enclosure is compact, which is great until you try to get it all to fit inside and then screw the cover on; watch your wire length and test fit before mounting. The box itself has 4 mounting holes in the back and they include silicone o rings to seal those up. There is an o ring for the front cover too. There are 2 knock outs for wiring, they include the screw in bushings with gaskets and tapered seal too. Nice touch. Be sure to put silicone (not included) on the seals. As for the comment about instructions, none packed in the box. Pretty intuitive though. I took out my multimeter to figure out the connections. There is a position 1, position 0 which is off, and position 2 on the switch. There are terminals on top (for position 1) and on the bottom (for position 2). How those work: for position 1 on the switch, you have 2 input terminals, call those 1A and 2A. When you flip the switch from 0 Off to 1 On, 1A connects to 3A and 2A connects to 4A. There is no continuity between 1A or 2A, nor between 3A and 4A. I needed 1A and 2A to share same input voltage wire, so I made a jumper wire and put it between 1A and 2A and then when I turn on the switch, both 3A and 4A output the same. All of this repeats with another set of terminals for position 2. And there is no continuity between switch position 1 and position 2. There are also 2 common terminal rails inside the enclosure as well those came in handy. I added an external connector to power my lights from a battery when the trailer is not connected to the tow vehicle too

Small Biz Owner
4.0 out of 5 stars Switch for solar system from inverter to shore power (not an easy install)
Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2023
Size: 3.15"x3.15"x3.7"Verified Purchase
Wish I had taken photos of the install. It was NOT easy. This is a 20A switch, which means you'll need to use 12 AWG wire. But it works as advertised!
For my project, I wanted the switch to be able to switch from power from the inverter to power from the grid. That way, my devices (fridge and small electronics) in our camp trailer would be powered no matter the source.
So I needed wires coming in from the grid (two go into the box, ground wire stays outside the box)
Then wires from the inverter (same deal, two into the plastic box, ground wire outside)
Then four wires coming out of the box that lead the AC circuit breaker and house outlets, plus two ground wires outside the box.
To wire it all up, those four ground wires got secured with a large red wire nut (max four 12 AWG) and many more wire nuts to the rest of the connections outside the box.
But the connections inside the box were the hardest. Getting all those wires through the little cutout holes was tough enough, but then trying to jam the whole front faceplate and box together and screw it all together was harder. Gotta make sure that all your wire is stripped properly (no nicks in the insulation) and you have screwed down the terminals on the switch really well. Fortunately, despite the entire switch being made of plastic (except for the terminals and internal electrical connections obviously), it seems fairly durable for light use. I would not trust it in a really heavy duty situation where it could get kicked or hit, but protected and out of the way seems fine.
Since this was in a mobile setting, I used stranded wire. Would probably have been easier with solid core wire. With the tight spaces in there, the risk was too great for a stray strand of wire to touch someplace it should not and cause a short, so I crimped ferrules onto the end of each wire and this made it SO MUCH easier and safer assembling it. Do yourself a favor and buy a kit with ferrules and ferrule crimper.
Long story short, I ended up not using the back end of the plastic box. I just left it off and installed the faceplate part that holds the switch anyways onto some 1/2" plywood. This made it way way way easier putting the whole thing together in still a tight space inside the camp trailer under the fridge
